Let me clarify this, only around 8% of energy in the US is sustainable energy, and that should change over the next 100 years or so, but it will not be a fast change. In fact the technology has not reached the point were that percentage can move very much at all. Yes that ability is in the works and companies like this are driving that change, but let now pretend that AI boo has anything to do with changing that 92% from oil to other. Even if we wanted to we could not go full alternative. Nuclear being the one possibility, currently there are 94 nuclear power plants in the US, producing around 50% of that 8%. So 4% of the energy in to US is produced by nuclear. In short, believe in the company not the pipe dream.
The AI boom will drive demand for explosive energy needs.  Solar and Nuclear will soar.

My best guess is that TCL will essentially supply low-cost Chinese ( their own ) wafers to Maxeon in Singapore, and cut all of Maxeon's in-house ingot and wafer manufacture that is the lion's share of their manufacturing costs. Maxeon will then apply their high performance finishing stages to the cells to get to 24-25% efficiency. The final product will be a bit more expensive that cheap Chinese cells at 20-22% efficiency that are nonetheless good quality cells. Hence Maxeon will be high performance higher ASP cells, but competitive given the efficiency. This will take not long to do btw since they just need to stop making wafers and import them instead to the free port of Singapore from China ( i.e. TCL ). That way TCL also evade the customs duty in the US and EU very nicely. And all of the ingot and wafer plant and machinery can be sold off back to China for a reasonable amount so nice for the cash position. Nothing else makes sense to me for this company, and this is a good plan. Still might go down more for while though.

I think the #1 thing hurting this stock is the silence. The gross lack of communication with the retail shareholders. Sadly I see this in a lot of stocks/companies. They cannot keep us up to date on speculations and direction because of industry secrets and liability. For me the bottom line is the facts. At this moment Maxeon has the #1 solar cell on earth. Not a boast, it holds the highest ratings of any cell manufactured. They are expanding production by building a billion dollar manufacturing plant in the US. These and many others are indicators of success. So the biggest question for you, is do you believe in the stock, or the company?

As I understand it, this company is not profitable because of expansion costs. So they lack financial growth but have physical growth in the form of new manufacturing facilities and equipment. Isn't it normal for a company which invests its profit into R&D, and expansion to show low or even negative profits until the expansion is completed and operational? Quick follow up question, who would lend them near a billion dollars, without seeing a business plan that illustrated the ability to earn back the funds to pay off said loan? Call me optimistic, but the evidence seems to indicate that many expert connected directly to the solar industry have put a lot of faith in Maxeon.

TLC as the majority shareholder will make the choice. I would have gone for 50:1 to give a price of around $10 to keep it well clear of the $1 requirement for Nasdaq listing. But what does it matter really? The main take away is that this is being done to keep the company within regulations which is a good sign that the company will continue at least for a while. The amount of money and effort TLC has put into this without actually buying Maxeon 100% is considerable, so that bodes well. They want a functioning if not profitable Maxeon. The question is why? The only answer that makes sense to me is that want a footfold outside of China and Singapore is logistically easy for them while being outside the US and Europe. Hence finishing TLC wafers with Maxeon final cell production steps quite likely is a perfect marriage of TLC's low-cost wafer manufacturing base in China with Maxeon's value adding low material cost stages in Singapore that are essentially automated. Then ship from the free port of Singapore into US and Europe without the Chinese tariffs. Makes complete business sense all around. Maxeon should be reasonably successful like this i.e. Chinese base costs ( the expensive and materials intensive wafers ) with top-end Maxeon 25% cell performance. Sounds like a winner to me. Maxeon management should have thought of this a long time ago.
